title: Bingo (1974 film)
text:
Bingo is a 1974 French-Canadian thriller directed by <a href="Jean-Claude%20Lord">Jean-Claude Lord</a>. The plot relates to Quebec's <a href="October%20Crisis">October Crisis</a> of 1970.
Synopsis.
Director <a href="Jean-Claude%20Lord">Jean-Claude Lord</a> exploits the post-October Crisis paranoia that was rampant in Quebec with considerable panache with this skilful melodrama. Although the story is not about the events leading up to the <a href="War%20Measures%20Act">War Measures Act</a>, it does draw upon the fabric and feelings of that time. A young photographer (<a href="R%C3%A9jean%20Gu%C3%A9nette">Réjean Guénette</a>) becomes unwittingly entangled in a terrorist organization, which engages in a plot against prominent politicians and business leaders before an upcoming election. The film was hugely popular in Quebec and established Lord as a major director with this, his third feature.
Soundtrack.
Lord's wife, and co-screenwriter, the actress <a href="Lise%20Thouin">Lise Thouin</a> released "Bingo", written by <a href="Michel%20Conte">Michel Conte</a> as a single.
Reception.
The film was well received in <a href="Quebec">Quebec</a> but failed to find an audience elsewhere, grossing $1.5 million in Canada.
